title-group.article-title: Electron-withdrawing/donating effects of substituents on the preparation of phosphinated 4,4′-diaminodiphenylmethane for soluble, anti-oxidative, and high-Tg polyimides

contrib-group.aff: Department of Chemical Engineering, National Chung Hsing University, Taichung, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Ching Hsuan Lin, Department of Chemical Engineering, National Chung Hsing University, Taichung, Taiwan Email: linch@nchu.edu.tw

abstract.p: In this work, we reveal a strategy to prepare a phosphinated 4,4′-diaminodiphenylmethane, 1,1-bis(4-aminophenyl)-1-(6-oxido-6H-dibenz <c, e<,2> oxaphosphorin-6-yl)methane (3). During the preparation, it was found that the effect of the electron withdrawing/donating characteristic of substituents is crucial to the synthesis. A reaction mechanism including nucleophilic addition, reduction, and electrophilic substitution is proposed. Based on diamine (3), a series of polyimides (4a–4d) were prepared. Polyimides 4 are readily soluble in some organic solvents, and can be solution cast into flexible and foldable films. They show high T g (310–390°C), high moduli (3.34–4.63 GPa), moderate coefficient of thermal expansion (46–58 ppm °C−1), good anti-oxidative stability (T d 5%: 480–537°C (N2); 456–504°C (air)), and good flame retardancy (VTM V-0 rating).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Generally, aromatic polyimides (PIs) are difficult to process because their insolubility and infusibility. It has been reported that incorporating bulky pendant into polymer chains can impart better organo-solubility because of the decreased packing density and crystallinity. 1
–10 It has also been reported that phosphorus-functionalized polymers can improve organo-solubility, adhesion to metal, flame retardancy and atomic oxygen resistance. 11
–30 Among them, the phosphinate type, with the O=P–O–C linkage in a cyclic form, display high thermal stability and flame retardancy. 14,18 –20,23,24 As a result, PIs with bulky phosphinate pendants seem to be a good strategy for better organo-solubility, high thermal stability, and flame retardancy.

4,4′-Diaminodiphenylmethane (DDM) is an important chemical for many industries. It is a starting material for 4,4′-methylenediisocyanate, epoxy (tetraglycidyl(diaminodiphenyl)methane), bismaleimide (1,1′-(methylenedi-p-phenylene)bismaleimide), and polyimides. It also acts as a chain extender for polyurethane, and a curing agent for epoxy resins. As a result, preparing a DDM-like structure with some functional groups would be interesting to the DDM-related industries.

In the authors’ previous paper, a phosphinated diamine, 1,1-bis(4-aminophenyl)-1-(6-oxido-6H -dibenz <;c, e>; <1,2> oxaphosphorin-6-yl)ethane was prepared from a one-pot reaction of 9,10-dihydro-oxa-10-phosphaphenanthrene-10-oxide (DOPO), 4-aminoacetophenone in excess aniline via a one-pot process. 14 In addition, the authors also reported an approach to prepare asymmetric diamines. 18 However, these approaches cannot be applied to prepare a DDM-like phosphinated diamine since the starting material, 4-aminobenzaldehyde, is not commercially available due to its instability. In the present study, a strategy to prepare a diamine with a DDM-like structure, 1,1-bis(4-aminophenyl)-1-(6-oxido-6H -dibenz <c, e>; <1,2> oxaphosphorin-6-yl)methane (3) using the stable 4- nitrobenzaldehyde as a starting material is reported. During the preparation, it was found that the electron withdrawing/donating characteristic of substituents has a huge influence on the reaction. The synthetic strategy, reaction mechanism, and the effect of the electro withdrawing/donating characteristic of substituent on the preparation of (3) are reported herein. Based on diamine (3), a series of PIs (4a-4d) were prepared from the one-step polymerization of (3) with various aromatic dianhydrides in m-cresol by high-temperature solution polymerization. PIs (5a–5d) based on DDM were also prepared in a conventional two-step procedure for property comparison. The properties such as solubility, crystallinity, and thermal properties of PIs 4 were examined and compared with PIs 5.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: 9,10-Dihydro-oxa-10-phosphaphenanthrene-10-oxide (DOPO, from TCI), 4-nitrobenzaldehyde (from Acros), meta-cresol (from Acros), aniline (from Acros), p-toluenesulfonic acid monohydrate (p-TSA, from Showa), and 4,4′-diaminodiphenyl methane (DDM, from Acros) were used as received. Pyromellitic dianhydride (PMDA, Acros) was dried at 170°C overnight before use. 3,3′,4,4′-Benzophenonetetracarboxylic dianhydride (BTDA, Acros), 4,4′-oxydiphthalic anhydride (ODPA, Chriskev), and 3,3′,4,4′-biphenyltetracarboxylic dianhydride (BPDA, Chriskev) were recrystallized from acetic anhydride. The solvents used were commercial products (HPLC grade) and used without further purification.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: The NMR measurements were performed using a Varian Inova 600 NMR in DMSO-d6 , and the chemical shift was calibrated by setting the chemical shift of DMSO-d6 as 2.49 ppm. IR Spectra were obtained in the standard wavenumber range of 400–4000 cm−1 using a Perkin-Elmer RX1 infrared spectrophotometer. High-resolution mass (HRMS) measurements were performed by a Finnigan/Thermo Quest MAT 95XL mass spectrometer by fast atom bombardment. Elemental analysis was performed on an Elementar Vario EL III. Wide-angle X-ray diffraction measurements were performed at room temperature by a MAC Science DMAX2000 X-ray diffractometer with monochromatic Cu Ka radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å, operating at 40 kV and 30 mA). The scanning rate was 3° min−1 over a range of 2θ = 5–40°. Differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) scans were obtained by a Perkin-Elmer DSC 7 in a nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 20°C min−1. Dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) was performed with a Perkin-Elmer Pyris Diamond DMA with a sample size of 5.0 cm × 1.0 cm × 0.002 cm. The storage modulus E′ and tan δ were determined as the sample was subjected to the temperature scan mode at a programmed heating rate of 5°C min−1 at a frequency of 1 Hz. The test was performed by tension mode with an amplitude of 25 μm. Thermo-mechanical analysis (TMA) was performed by a SII TMA/SS6100 at a heating rate of 5°C min−1. The onset of transition in dimension was defined as T g, and coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) before T g was defined by calculating the TMA data from 100 to 250°C. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed by a Perkin-Elmer Diamond TGA at a heating rate of 20°C min−1 in a nitrogen atmosphere from 100 to 800°C. Gel permeation chromatography (GPC) was carried out on a Hitachi L2130 with a UV detector (L2400) using N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) as the eluent at 60°C with a flow rate of 1.0 mL min−1. The data were calibrated with polystyrene standard. The flame retardancy of the PIs was performed by a UL-94VTM vertical thin test. In that test, an 8 in × 2in sample is wrapped around a 1/2 in mandrel and then taped on one end. The mandrel is removed, leaving a cone-shaped sample that is relatively rigid. The two flame applications were 3 s instead of 10 s. After the first ignition, the flame was removed and the time for the polymer to self-extinguish (t 1) was recorded. Cotton ignition would be noted if polymer dripping occurs during the test. After cooling, the second ignition was performed on the same sample and the self-extinguishing time (t 2) and dripping characteristics were recorded. If t 1 plus t 2 is less than 10 s without any dripping, the polymer is considered to be a VTM-0 material. If t 1 plus t 2 is in the range of 10–30 s without any dripping, the polymer is considered to be a VTM-1 material.

sec.title: Synthesis of intermediate (1)
sec.p: (1) 10.0 g, 10% Pd/C 0.2 g, and DMF 80 g were introduced into a 160 mL Parr stirred reactors. The reaction system was purged with nitrogen for 30 min before introducing hydrogen. The pressure of the autoclave was maintained at about 9.5 kg cm−2 under a hydrogen atmosphere for 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was filtered to remove Pd/C, and the filtrate was poured into water (500 mL) under stirring, yielding a precipitate. After drying the precipitate at 100 °C, yellow powder (8.12 g, 88% yield) was obtained. HR-MS(FAB+) m/z: calcd. for C19H16O3NP 337.0868; anal., 338.0951 (M+1) + , C19H17O3NP. 1H-NMR (DMSO-d6 ), δ = 4.89 (1H, H1), 5.04 (1H, H1′), 5.08 (4H, NH2), 6.01 (1H, OH′), 6.08 (1H, OH), 6.47 (2H, H16 ′), 6.50 (2H, H16), 6.93 (2H, H15), 6.98 (2H, H15′), 7.15 (1H, H12 ′), 7.16 (1H, H1 2), 7.24 (1H, H1 0), 7.28 (1H, H10′), 7.40 (1H, H11′), 7.43 (1H, H11), 7.49 (1H, H4), 7.51 (1H, H3), 7.56 (1H, H4′), 7.76 (2H, H5 and H5′), 7.87 (1H, H3′), 8.11 (1H, H9 ′), 8.14 (1H, H9), 8.19 (2H, H6 and H6′). 13C-NMR (DMSO-d6 ), δ = 71.13 (C1), 71.91 (C1 ′), 113.18 (C1 6 and C1 6′), 119.49 (C12), 119.62 (C12 ′), 121.40 (C7), 121.67 (C7 ′), 123.07 (C1 0′), 123.21 (C1 4), 123.24 (C1 4′), 123.42 (C2), 123.47 (C2′), 123.71 (C10), 123.98 (C6′), 124.18 (C6), 125.28 (C9′), 125.47 (C9), 127.90 (C4), 128.09 (C15), 128.26 (C4′), 128.50 (C15′), 130.41 (C11′), 130.56 (C11), 130.82 (C3′), 131.73 (C3), 133.18 (C5), 133.38 (C5 ′), 135.89 (C8 and C8′), 148.35 (C17 ′), 148.39 (C17), 149.98 (C1 3), 150.04 (C1 3 ′). 31P-NMR, (DMSO-d6 ), δ = 32.23 (s). FTIR (KBr): 3400–3200 cm−1 (NH2), 3350–3100 cm−1 (OH), 1613 cm−1 (N–H), 1200 cm−1 (P = O).

sec.title: Synthesis of intermediate (2)
sec.p: (1) 10.0 g, 10% Pd/C 0.2 g, and DMF 80 g were introduced into a 160 mL Parr stirred reactors. The reaction system was purged with nitrogen for 30 min before introducing hydrogen. The pressure of the autoclave was maintained at about 9.5 kg cm−2 under a hydrogen atmosphere for 24 h. Then, the reaction mixture was filtered to remove Pd/C, and the filtrate was poured into water (500 mL) under stirring, yielding a precipitate. After drying the precipitate at 100 °C, yellow powder (8.12 g, 88% yield) was obtained. HR-MS(FAB+) m/z: calcd. for C19H16O3NP 337.0868; anal., 338.0951 (M+1) + , C19H17O3NP. 1H-NMR (DMSO-d6 ), δ = 4.89 (1H, H1), 5.04 (1H, H1′), 5.08 (4H, NH2), 6.01 (1H, OH′), 6.08 (1H, OH), 6.47 (2H, H16 ′), 6.50 (2H, H16), 6.93 (2H, H15), 6.98 (2H, H15′), 7.15 (1H, H12 ′), 7.16 (1H, H1 2), 7.24 (1H, H1 0), 7.28 (1H, H10′), 7.40 (1H, H11′), 7.43 (1H, H11), 7.49 (1H, H4), 7.51 (1H, H3), 7.56 (1H, H4′), 7.76 (2H, H5 and H5′), 7.87 (1H, H3′), 8.11 (1H, H9 ′), 8.14 (1H, H9), 8.19 (2H, H6 and H6′). 13C-NMR (DMSO-d6 ), δ = 71.13 (C1), 71.91 (C1 ′), 113.18 (C1 6 and C1 6′), 119.49 (C12), 119.62 (C12 ′), 121.40 (C7), 121.67 (C7 ′), 123.07 (C1 0′), 123.21 (C1 4), 123.24 (C1 4′), 123.42 (C2), 123.47 (C2′), 123.71 (C10), 123.98 (C6′), 124.18 (C6), 125.28 (C9′), 125.47 (C9), 127.90 (C4), 128.09 (C15), 128.26 (C4′), 128.50 (C15′), 130.41 (C11′), 130.56 (C11), 130.82 (C3′), 131.73 (C3), 133.18 (C5), 133.38 (C5 ′), 135.89 (C8 and C8′), 148.35 (C17 ′), 148.39 (C17), 149.98 (C1 3), 150.04 (C1 3 ′). 31P-NMR, (DMSO-d6 ), δ = 32.23 (s). FTIR (KBr): 3400–3200 cm−1 (NH2), 3350–3100 cm−1 (OH), 1613 cm−1 (N–H), 1200 cm−1 (P = O).

sec.title: Synthesis of diamine (3)
Preparation of PIs
sec.p: Syntheses of PIs 4 are exemplified by the synthesis of 4a from the condensation of diamine (3) and PMDA. (3) 1.00 g (2.42 mmol), PMDA 0.5279 g (2.42 mmol), isoqunoline (3 drops) and m-cresol 6.12 g (20 wt.% solid content) were introduced into a 100 mL, round-bottom flask equipped with a nitrogen inlet and magnetic stirrer. The reaction was carried out at reflux temperature for 12 h. Then, the viscous polyimides solution was poured into methanol. The precipitate was washed by reflux methanol in a soxhlet. The polymer solid was dissolved in NMP (20 wt.% solid content) and casted on glass by an automatic film applicator, and dried at 80°C overnight and 100°C (1 h), 200°C (2 h), respectively. The other PIs (4b–4d) were prepared by a similar procedure. IR absorption: 1776 cm−1 (C = O asymmetric stretch of imide), 1723 cm−1 (C = O symmetric stretch of imide), 1370 cm−1 (C–N stretch), 1119 and 752 cm−1 (imide ring deformation) 1206 cm−1 (P = O), 917 cm−1 (P–O–Ph). For property comparison, DDM-based PIs (5) were prepared, but they are prepared by a traditional two-step procedure due to the insolubility of PIs (5) in organic solvent. Syntheses of PIs 5 are exemplified by the synthesis of 5a from the condensation of DDM and PMDA. To a 100 mL three-neck, round-bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer, nitrogen inlet, DDM 0.2974 g (1.50 mmole), and CaH2-dried DMAc 3.87 g were added. After the monomer had dissolved completely, the reactor was placed into an ice-bath cooling system. After the reaction mixture reached 3–5°C, PMDA 0.3272 g (1.50 mmole) was added quickly and reacted at that temperature for 12 h. Then, the viscous poly(amic acid) was cast on glass by an automatic film applicator. The resulting poly(amic acid) thin films were dried at 80°C overnight and imidized at 100°C (1 h), 200°C (1 h) and 300°C (1 h), respectively.

sec.title: Synthesis of diamine (3)
sec.p:
Generally, aromatic diamines could be prepared by strong acid-catalyzed condensation of ketone or aldehyde compounds with excess aniline. 31
–34 In addition to strong acid-catalyzed condensation, Kray et al., 35 Zolotukhin et al., 36
–41 and Ueda et al. 42 have reported the super acid-catalyzed electrophilic chemistry. According to the similar principle, biphenylene phosphinate-substituted DDM (3) was prepared in an acid-catalyzed reaction (Scheme 1, route a).

caption.p: Two synthetic strategies of preparing (3). Note that route (b) is an unsuccessful one.

sec.p: In the first step, DOPO attacked the aldehyde of 4-nitrobenzaldehyde through a nucleophilic addition, forming compound (1). In the second step, the nitro group of (1) was reduced to amino group, forming compound (2). In the third step, aniline attacked (2) through an acid-catalyzed electrophilic substitution, forming diamine (3). Referring to the reaction mechanism reported by Cho et al. 34, and Kray et al. 35 , a reaction mechanism for the electrophilic substitution of aniline and (2) is proposed in Scheme 2.

caption.p: Proposed mechanism for the electrophilic substitution. Note that the carbocation of (2′) is stabilized by the electron-donating amino group.

sec.p:
As shown in Scheme 2, the secondary hydroxyl group of (2) is initially protonated by acid. Then, the protonated hydroxyl group dissociated to yield intermediate (2′) with a secondary carbocation, which can be stabilized by the resonance of the electro-donating amino group. Finally, aniline attacked the carbocation through an electrophilic substitution, yielding (3) successfully. In addition to route (a), an attempt was made to prepare (3) by the procedure shown in route (b), Scheme 1. In that route, aniline was supposed to attack (1) via an acid-catalyzed electrophilic substitution, forming (4). Then, the nitro group of (4) will be reduced to amino group, forming (3). However, the electrophilic substitution of aniline on (1) did not occur under various reaction conditions. Scheme 3 shows the structure of carbocation intermediate (1′) for electrophilic substation. As shown in Scheme 3, the carbocation of (1′) is destabilized by the electron-withdrawing nitro group, so it is an unstable carbocation. As a result, the electrophilic substitution cannot be carried out successfully. In contrast, as shown in Scheme 2, the carbocation of (2′) is stabilized by the resonance of the electron-donating amino group, so intermediate (2′) is a stable one. The experiment data show that a carbocation with an electron-donating group prompts the electrophilic substitution although it has been reported that an electron-withdrawing substituent on the cationic center can increase the electrophilicity toward aromatic. 43 –45 Therefore, it is thought that the reason for this difference between this work and previous work 43
–45 is more complex than just carbocation stabilization or destabilization. Therefore, it is thought that the reason for this difference between this work and previous work 43
–45 is more complex than just carbocation stabilization or destabilization. Detailed analysis in future work is required to make a conclusion.

caption.p: The structure of carbocation intermediate (1′). Note that the carbocation of (1′) is unstabilized by the electron-withdrawing nitro group.

sec.title: Characterization of (1–3)
sec.p: Figure 1 shows the 1 H-NMR spectra of (1–3). For intermediate (1), the phosphorus and aliphatic carbon (C1) are both chiral centers, resulting in two pairs of enantiomers. Therefore, two sets of NMR data were resulted. Two OH signals at 6.65 and 6.77 ppm, two H1 signals at 5.45 and 5.65 ppm, and two sets of Ar–H signals at 7.12–8.23 ppm confirmed that two pairs of enantiomers were found in the preparation. For intermediate (2), two sets of NMR signals were also noted for the same reason. The amino peak at 5.08 ppm and the upshift of the Ar–H signals, especially the signals of H15, H15′, H16 and H16′, confirm the reduction of the nitro group. For diamine (3), the appearance of H19–H20 signals, along with the disappearance of the OH signal of (2), supports the electrophilic substitution. Only one set of 1H-NMR data was obtained because the aliphatic carbon (C1) is not a chiral center, which can be confirmed through the simplificaiton of the Ar–H signals. The structures of (1–3) were also characterized by 13 C-NMR spectra and the assignments of each carbon were assisted by the 1 H– 1 H COSY and 1 H– 13 C HETCOR NMR spectra (not shown for brief). The results are in good agreement with the proposed structure of (1–3).

sec.title: Polyimide synthesis
sec.p: PIs 4 were prepared by reacting (3) with an equal mole of dianhydrides (a–d) in m-cresol by high-temperature solution polymerization (Scheme 4). A few drops of isoqunoline were added to catalyze the polymerization. For solution polymerization, the prerequisite is that the resulting PI should be soluble in the reaction solvent. In this case, a homogeneous solution was achieved during the reaction, probably due to the bulky phosphinate pendant that enhances the solubility. According to the principle of NMR, a larger chemical shift of amino signal means a lower electron density of the amino group, and corresponds to a lower reactivity. In this case, the chemical shift of the amino group of (3) is at 5.0 ppm, which is the same as that (5.0 ppm) of DDM, suggesting that the electron-withdrawing P = O bond did not affect the electron density of the amino groups. Therefore, the reactivity of (3) is expected to be similar to that of DDM, and PIs with moderate-to-high molecular weight are expected. As listed in Table 1, the number-average molecular weights of 4b and 4c range from 2.4 to 2.6 × 104 g mol−1, and the weight-average molecular weights range from 3.9 to 4.7 × 104 g mol−1, demonstrating moderate molecular weight and reflecting the purity and reactivity of (3).

caption.p: Molecular weight and solubility data of polyimides 4.

fn.p: aNumber average molecular weight and weight average molecular weight are relative to polystyrene standard, using DMF as eluent.
bSolubility was tested with a 5 mg sample in 0.5 mL of solvent at room temperature.
cNot available due to poor solubility in DMF.
d+, soluble; +h, soluble on heating; +–, partially soluble on heating; –, insoluble on heating.

sec.title: Organosolubility and crystallinity
sec.p: The solubility data of PIs 4 are listed in Table 1. In contrast with PIs 5 which are insoluble in organic solvents, PIs 4 display much better solubility. The bulky phosphinate pendant, which led to disrupting packing, should be responsible for the improved solubility. According to the wide-angle X-ray diffraction pattern of PIs 4 (Figure 2), all the PIs 4 are amorphous. The bulky phosphinate pendant should be responsible for the amorphous characteristic and the improved solubility.

caption.p: Wide-angle X-ray diffraction patterns of PIs 4.

sec.title: Thermal properties
sec.p: DMA and TMA were applied to evaluate the dynamic mechanical properties and thermal mechanical properties of PIs 4 since they display flexibility and toughness. Figure 3 shows the DMA thermograms of PIs 4d and 5d. The T g obtained from the peak temperature of tan δ for 4d is 344°C, which is 25°C higher than that of 5d. In addition, the storage modulus of 4d is much higher than 5d. The phenomena of higher T g and modulus were also observed for the other PIs (Table 2). The bulky phosphinate pendant that hinders the rotation of PI chains might be responsible for the higher T g and modulus. In addition, the polar P = O bond that results in a stronger intermolecular interaction might also be responsible for the result. Figure 4 shows the TMA thermograms of PIs 4d and 5d. The coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) of 4d at 100–250°C is 46 ppm °C−1, which is similar to that of 5d (43 ppm °C−1), indicating that introducing the bulk phosphinate pendant will not scarify the dimensional stability. As can be seen in Table 2, the CTEs of other PIs 4 at 100–250°C range from 46 to 58 ppm °C−1, demonstrating moderate-to-high dimensional stability.

caption.p: Thermal and mechanical properties of PIs 4.

fn.p: aMeasured by DMA at a heating rate of 5°C min−1; storage modulus (E′) is recorded at 50°C.
bMeasured by TMA at a heating rate of 10°C min−1.
cCoefficient of thermal expansions, recorded from 100 to 250°C.
gData in parentheses are those of PIs 5.

sec.title: Optical transparency
sec.p: The cutoff wavelength of the PIs was measured by UV-vis spectroscopy, and the results are listed in Table 2. The cutoff wavelengths of PIs 4 range from 381 to 401 nm, which are shorter than those (397–438 nm) of PIs 5, demonstrating the lighter color characteristic of PIs 4. The bulky phosphinate pendant, which separated the PI chains and thus reduced the charge transfer complex, should be responsible for the lighter color.

sec.title: Thermal stability and flame retardancy
sec.p: The thermal stability of PIs 4 was evaluated by TGA. In the nitrogen atmosphere, the 5 wt.% degradation temperatures of PIs 4 range from 480 to 537°C, and the char yields range from 66 to 71%. In the air atmosphere, the 5 wt.% degradation temperatures range from 456 to 504°C, and the char yields range from 58 to 64%. The high decomposition temperature and high char yield in the atmosphere demonstrate good anti-oxidative characteristic of PIs 4. As to the flame retardancy, according to the UL-94VTM vertical thin test, the t 1 + t 2 is less than 4 s for PIs 4, so they belong to the VTM-0 grade. Although PI 5 also possess VTM-0 grade, they are organo-insoluble, which limits their application potential. The combination of organo-solubility and flame retardancy makes PIs 4 attractive for industrial application.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A phosphinated diaminodiphenylmethane was successfully prepared via the procedures of nucleophilic addition, reduction, and electrophilic substitution. It was found that the stabilization of the carbocation is a crucial factor to the electrophilic substitution. When the carbocation is destabilized by the electron-withdrawing nitro group, the electronic substitution cannot occur. However, if the nitro group is reduced to an amino group, the carbocation is stabilized by the strong electron-donating amino group, and the electrophilic substitution can take place successfully. All the PIs 4 are tough and foldable. They show higher T g, higher modulus, lighter color and better solubility than PIs 5. TGA data show that PIs 4 exhibits high decomposition temperature and high char yield in the atmosphere, demonstrating good anti-oxidative stability. The combination of flexibility, high glass transition temperature, high anti-oxidative stability, excellent flame retardancy, and improved organosolubility, makes PIs 4 promising polymers for electronic applications.
